title: How to Knit an Arm Scarf

steps.headline: Choose a super bulky yarn in your favorite color.
steps.description: Select a skein of yarn that's 74 yards (68 m) long and 6 ounces (170 g). Ensure that the yarn is soft so it makes a comfortable scarf to wear.You'll also need a large crochet hook, if you'd like to weave the ends in.

steps.headline: Find both ends of the yarn and bring them together.
steps.description: Remove the wrapper from the yarn and find the loose ends of the yarn. 1 end of the yarn will probably be stuck into the center of the skein, so you'll need to dig around to find it. Hold both of the ends together in the palm of your hand.You'll double-knit with 2 strands of yarn to make a thick, chunky scarf.

steps.headline: Pull out a 3 feet (0.91 m) tail of yarn and make a slip knot.
steps.description: To make a slip knot on your arm, hold 1 of your arms in front of you so the palm of your hand is facing you. Drape the double strand of yarn over your hand and gather the working yarn and yarn tail together below your hand. Twist the loop of yarn and use your hand to pull the working yarn through the loop.

steps.headline: Tighten the slip knot and slide it onto your arm.
steps.description: Pull on the yarn to tighten the slip knot a little. Then slide the loop onto your right arm. Ensure that the loop is at least halfway up your arm.Tighten the slip knot again so the loop doesn't slide around your arm. This loop counts as your first stitch.

steps.headline: Position the working yarn through the fingers of your left hand.
steps.description: Wind the working yarn between the index and middle finger of your left hand and use your ring and pinky fingers to hold the yarn to your palm.To keep it out of the way, wrap the tail around the thumb of your left hand and use the ring and pinky fingers to hold the tail towards your palm.

steps.headline: Use the working yarn to cast on.
steps.description: Bend your right wrist down and move your hand under the tail strand. Lift your wrist over the 2 other lines of working yarn and then scoop your right hand fingers under the working yarn that's farthest from you. Bring your hand through the yarn to make a loop and pull it onto your right arm.You've just cast on 1 new stitch.

steps.headline: Cast on a total of 10 stitches.
steps.description: Since the slip knot that you started with counts as your first stitch, you'll need to cast on 9 stitches for a total of 10 stitches. Keep the loops tight enough that they won't slide off your arm.If your loops aren't tight enough, your scarf will be loose.

steps.headline: Make a knit stitch onto your left arm.
steps.description: Hold the working yarn with your right hand so it's far away from you and use your left hand to pull the stitch closest to your wrist off and over the working yarn. This will make a knit stitch that you can slide through your left hand and onto your left arm.To make the garter stitch, knit every stitch of each row.

steps.headline: Tighten the stitch on your left arm.
steps.description: Use your left hand to pull on the working yarn. At the same time, use your right hand to slide the knot towards the loop on your left arm.Keep doing this until the stitch is tight on your left arm.

steps.headline: Knit the remaining 9 stitches.
steps.description: Remember to hold the working yarn with your right hand before you pull a stitch off using your left hand. Slide your left hand through the loop and bring the stitch onto your left arm.Repeat this for the remaining stitches on your right arm. Keep the stitches tight as you work so your scarf isn't loose.

steps.headline: Knit the second row.
steps.description: Since you'll be doing a knit stitch but in reverse, keep the working arm close to you. Hold the working yarn in your left hand and use your right hand to pull the stitch closest to your wrist off and over the working yarn. Then slide your right arm through the loop and grab the working yarn with the right hand. Tighten the loop on your right arm before you knit the rest of the stitches on the row.Remember to grab the working yarn with your left hand before working each stitch. Keep it at the back of the work for this row so you make knit stitches.

steps.headline: Knit 15 more rows.
steps.description: Knit every stitch for the next 15 rows. It's important to keep the working yarn in your right hand so it's in the front and away from you when you're working the stitches on your right arm. Then bring the working yarn to your left hand and close to your torso when you knit the stitches on your left arm.The left arm stitches will be even rows. The right arm stitches will be odd rows, so remember to keep the working yarn in front for the odd rows.

steps.headline: Knit 2 stitches from your left arm onto your right.
steps.description: Once you've finished 17 rows, the stitches will all be on your left arm. Knit 2 stitches onto your right arm so you can begin to bind off the stitches.

steps.headline: Lift the first stitch over the second stitch and pull it off.
steps.description: Use your left hand to pick up the stitch on your right arm that's closest to you. Lift it up and pull it over the other stitch so it slides off your hand. Pull on the working yarn to tighten it a little.You'll now have just 1 stitch on your right arm.

steps.headline: Knit 1 more stitch and bind off a stitch.
steps.description: Continue to make 1 knit stitch onto your right arm so there are 2 stitches on it. Then lift up and slide the closest stitch off.You should have 1 stitch left on your right arm again.

steps.headline: Bind off the remaining stitches from the left arm.
steps.description: Keep knitting 1 stitch and binding off 1 stitch at a time until you reach the end of the row. You should have 1 stitch remaining on your right arm.

steps.headline: Bind off the final stitch.
steps.description: Hold the working yarn with your right hand and use your left hand to pull the last stitch off of your right arm. Then use your right hand to pull up gently on the loop.This will tighten it a little so you're left with a hanging loop.

steps.headline: Cut the working yarn to leave a 2 feet (0.61 m) tail.
steps.description: Leave the loop and measure 2 feet (0.61 m) of the working yarn from the base of the loop. Use scissors to cut the working yarn. Then pull the tail completely through the loop.If you're planning to make the scarf into an infinity scarf, leave a 3 feet (0.91 m) to 4 feet (1.2 m) tail that you can use to stitch the ends together.

steps.headline: Weave in the tails.
steps.description: Consider wrapping 1 of the yarn tails around a large crochet hook. Insert the hook into the stitch next to the base of the yarn tail and bring the yarn through. Keep weaving the yarn into the next few stitches and then cut it so it's close to the fabric of the scarf.Repeat this with the tail at the other end of the scarf.
